definition: a yellowish surface froth or sediment that occurs especially in saccharine liquids (such as fruit juices) in which it promotes alcoholic fermentation, consists largely of cells of a fungus (such as the saccharomyces, Saccharomyces cerevisiae), and is used especially in the making of alcoholic liquors and as a leaven in baking
a commercial product containing yeast fungi in a moist or dry medium
a unicellular fungus that is present and functionally active in yeast, usually has little or no mycelium, and reproduces by budding, any of various similar fungi
the foam or spume of waves
something that causes ferment or activity
examples: were all seething with the yeast of revolt
